settings.text: Herpes zoster, another name for shingles, is a contagious viral infection that results in a painful rash. The varicella-zoster virus, which also causes chickenpox, is to blame for this viral infection. Shingles can strike anyone at any age, but it typically affects people over the age of 50. As you age, your risk of getting shingles rises. Welzo users should read this article to learn more about Shingles.

settings.heading: What are the symptoms of Shingles?

settings.text: Pain is the most typical symptom of shingles.A rash that typically develops on one side of your body, a fever, a headache, and chills are some additional symptoms.Blisters make up the rash, which eventually develops into scabs.Shingles can also result in severe fatigue.

Although shingles cannot be cured, there are treatments that can lessen the symptoms.These include anti-inflammatory drugs, antiviral drugs, and pain relievers.A corticosteroid medication may also be suggested by your doctor in some circumstances to help reduce inflammation.Typically, shingles disappear on their own in two to four weeks.Postherpetic neuralgia, a type of chronic pain, can occur in some people.After the rash has disappeared, this kind of pain may linger for months or even years.There are remedies that can help with this kind of pain relief.

settings.heading: What is the outlook for people with Shingles?

settings.text: For those who have shingles, the prognosis is typically positive.The majority of patients will fully recover from the infection without any problems.Some individuals, however, may endure chronic pain or other issues.Postherpetic neuralgia is a severe complication of shingles that can occur.After the rash has disappeared, this kind of pain may linger for months or even years.Shingles can also result in eye issues that can result in blindness.Your outlook will worsen if you experience even one of these issues.A painful rash is brought on by the viral infection known as shingles.The varicella-zoster virus, which also causes chickenpox, is to blame for this viral infection.Shingles can strike anyone at any age, but it typically affects people over the age of 50.

settings.heading: How is shingles different to chickenpox?

settings.text: There is no known treatment for shingles, but there are ways to lessen the symptoms.These consist of anti-inflammatory, antiviral, and painkilling drugs.In certain circumstances, your doctor might also suggest a corticosteroid medication to help reduce inflammation.Within two to four weeks, shingles typically disappear on their own.Postherpetic neuralgia is a chronic pain condition that some people may experience.Even years after the rash has disappeared, this kind of pain can linger.This kind of pain can be treated with certain procedures.

Although there is no guaranteed way to avoid getting shingles, there are some things you can do to lower your risk.These consist of receiving the shingles vaccine and avoiding contact with shingles sufferers.You can get a shingles vaccine to help lower your risk of developing the condition if you've already had chickenpox.For those over 50, the shingles vaccine is advised.
